turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Don't hurt me!  Don't hurt me!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not going to hurt you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me,

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wendy!

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away...!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Darling, light of my life, I'm not going to hurt you.  You didn't let me finish my sentence.  I said 'I'm not going to hurt you... I'm just going to bash your brains in!'  I'm going to bash them right the fuck in.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not going to hurt you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me!

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me!  Please...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Stop swinging the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Put the bat down, Wendy.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stop it!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wendy give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay... stay away!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Stay away from me.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Jack, stay away from me!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Stop swinging the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Get down.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Go away from me.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wendy...

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Go away.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Go away.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Give me the bat.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I'll bring back a doctor.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wendy...

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I'm gonna go now.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wendy...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Mr. Ullman?

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm Jack Torrance.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh, well - come on in Jack.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Very nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nice to meet you, Mr. Ullman.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Have any trouble finding us?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Oh, no problem at all.  I made the trip in three and a half hours.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Well, that's very good time, very good.  Please sit down a minute.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: JAck, just make yourself at home. Would you like some coffee?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, if you are going to have some, I wouldn't mind.  Thanks.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Susie.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Let's see, where were we?  Yes.  I was about to explain that eh... our season here runs from oh May 15th to October 30th and then we close down completely until the following May.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Do you mind if I ask why you do that?  It seems to me that the skiing up here would be fantastic.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh, it sure would be

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Only in a very general way.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: ...the winters can be fantastically cruel, and the basic idea is to...to cope with the very costly damage and depreciation which can occur.  And this consists mainly of running the boiler, heating different parts of the hotel on a daily rotating basis, repairing damage as it occurs and doing repairs, so that the elements can't get a foothold.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, that sounds fine to me.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Physically, it's not a very demanding job.  The only thing that can get a bit trying up here during the winter is eh... the tremendous sense of isolation.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, that just happens to be exactly what I'm looking for.  I'm eh... I'm outlining a new writing project, and eh...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: five months of peace is just what I want.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: That's very good Jack, because eh... for some people eh solitude and isolation...

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: can of itself be a problem.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Not for me.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: How about your wife and son?  How do you think they'll take to it?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They'll love it.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Great...

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: been known to give a few people second thoughts about the job.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm intrigued.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: I don't suppose they eh told you anything in Denver about the tragedy we had up here during the winter of 1970?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I don't believe they did.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Well, my predecessor in this job

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: The police eh... they thought that it was what the old-timers used to call cabin-fever, a kind of claustrophobic reaction which can occur when people are

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: shut in together over long periods of time.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, that is eh quite a story.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Well, obviously some people can be

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: put off by the idea of staying alone in a place where something like that actually happened.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, you can rest assured Mr. Ullman, that's not going to happen with me, and eg as far as my wife is concerned, I am sure she'll be absolutely fascinated when I tell her about it.  She's a confirmed ghost story and horror film addict.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Good morning Jack.  I hope you haven't been waiting too long.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No problem.  In fact we had time to grab a bite to eat.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Good.  Glad you made it before they shut down the kitchen.  Is your family having a look around?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No, my son's discovered the games room.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh... Has your luggage been brought in?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Right there.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh fine.  Well in view of all the ground that we to cover today, I suggest we go and have a quick look at your apartment and then get started straight away.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'd better collect my family first.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Yes, very cosy for a family, and if you feel like spreading out you have the rest of the hotel to move around in.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, it's very... homely.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: This is our Colorado Lounge.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh, it's beautiful.  My God, this place is fantastic, isn't it hon?

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Yes, I believe they are based mainly on Navajo and Apache motifs.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh well they're really gorgeous. As a matter of fact this is probably the most gorgeous hotel I've ever seen.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: even before anybody knew what a jet set was.  We've had four presidents who stayed here, lots of movie stars.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Royalty?

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: All the best people.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: This is the staff wing of the hotel. None of the other bedrooms are heated during the winter.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: As a matter of fact we eh... brought a decorator in from Chicago just last year to refurbish this part of the hotel.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh well he sure did a beautiful job. Pink and gold are my favorite colors.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Oh...well this is our gold ballroom.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh, I'll say.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: We can accommodate up to three hundred people here very comfortably.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Boy, I bet you we could really have a good party in this room, huh hon?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Thank you, Susie.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: How're you getting on?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: It's amazing how much activity is going on today.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Yes, well the guests and some of the staff left yesterday, but the last day is always very hectic - everybody wants to be on their way as early as possible.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: By five o'clock tonight, you'll never know anybody was ever here.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Just like a ghost ship, huh?

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Bill, I'd like you to meet Jack Torrance.

turns.speaker: WATSON
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Jack is going to take care of the Overlook for this winter.  I would like you to take him around the place as soon as we are through.

turns.speaker: WATSON
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Jack is a schoolteacher.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: What time does the plane leave?

turns.speaker: WATSON
turns.text: Eight thirty.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Well, that still gives up plenty of time to go over everything first.

turns.speaker: ULLMAN
turns.text: Bill, would you have the Torrances' things brought in their apartment.

turns.speaker: WATSON
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Holy-jumped-up-baldheaded-Jesus-CHRIST!

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Uncle Al-

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: If Father Lowe is an innocent little lamb, why hasn't he picked up the telephone and called Constable Haller to tell him Marty's sending poison-pen letters?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I don't accept the idea that he knows who his letter writer is, Jane. Because I don't accept the idea that there was a big bad wolf who saw Marty in his wheelchair.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Why hasn't he picked up the phone and told Constable Haller that someone is sending him poison-pen letters?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Lowe's car-?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Blue. This blue.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Would you kids mind telling me how this guy Lowe became a werewolf to begin with?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe he doesn't know, either.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Can I tell you kids something?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Sure, Uncle Al.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: When me and sissy were kids, we were just like you two.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: The moon's not down yet...

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Damn near. Now I'll sit up with this stupid gun in my lap because I promised, but you two are going to bed. Go on, now, scoot.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You always take his side because he's a cripple! Well, it's not my fault that he's a cripple!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Come on, Jane- it was Brady's idea. I couldn't stop him.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Brady's a booger and so are you!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Did he really get his head cut off, Dad? That's what Brady said.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: If you don't stop it I'm going to vomit. I mean it.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What's the money for?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: A new pair of panty hose. Is it enough?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I don't want your money. You're a booger.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It was Brady's idea, Jane. Honest to God. Please take the money. I want to make up.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Mom was really mad at him this time, wasn't she?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What do you expect, when he comes in smelling like a brewery and looking like an unmade bed?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Stop it!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yes. Go away.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Let me help you up.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Marty? You okay? You've just been sitting here all morning.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Where's Mom?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Went shopping. Why?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jane, I have to talk to you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jane... you don't have to do that.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Don't tell me what I have to do and what I don't, booger-brains.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Will you marry me, Jane?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Please, Uncle Al.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Will you?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Don't you touch me, snotbrains!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jane-

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Are you all right, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: All except my legs... I don't think I can walk.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You're a real booger, you know it?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: You booger.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's what my sister says, too. Pretty soon I'm going to start checking the mirror to see if I'm turning green.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Not bad, huh? My Uncle Al took off the regular muffler and put on a Cherry Bomb.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Glasspack. He said he'd come over sometime this summer and we'd soup up the engine... but now I dunno. He's getting a divorce and he's in the doghouse with my mother.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: For getting a divorce?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well... it is his third.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I used to see her every day, and she never knew what was going to happen to her, and neither did I! I mean I know how stupid that sounds, but...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, take it easy. I know how you feel.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: There's something else scary.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I've been hearing noises in there.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What kind of noises?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Rattling. Rustling.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Rats...

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: And my dad says it's kids. But it's not rats and it's not kids. It's-

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Well, it's probably nothing. I'm just spooked since... you know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah... but if you hear any more noises, tell your father. Okay?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Okay. Have you got enough gas to get home, Marty?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Ralph Houk! You can't bet a manager! Stone the crows!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Okay, okay. Dwight Evans.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Piss on him. Piss on all the Red Sox.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Mom-!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Let the boy finish the game, Nan.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You all right, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: There's a saying- so-and-so was better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick. You ever hear that one?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Well, I'm not sure that was. Christ! They better get the guy.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Uncle Al, what if it's not a guy?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What if it's some kind of monster?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What's going on at Owen's, Uncle Al?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: A bunch of men getting ready to pretend they're Clint Eastwood... Marty, didn't anybody ever tell you that the only monsters are in comic books and drive-in movies?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It isn't enough that the monster killed all those people- that he killed Brady. Now he's got them to cancel the fair.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: And the fireworks. Hand me that box, Marty.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, okay, the fireworks. Jane thinks that's all I'm mad about, but it's not. Them doing that is just a... a...

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: It's just an outward symbol of everything that's inwardly wrong in this town. Not bad, huh? I read Sherwood Anderson in college. I can jive that shit all day.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well... I like it that you always know how to say things, Uncle Al.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I'll give you the telephone numbers of my ex-wives, dear boy- they'll be interested to hear that.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Don't call me dear boy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: But you are, you know- you are my dear boy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Your mom's not around, is she?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: She and dad are out back lighting the barbecue. Jane's walking around like she's King Shit of Turd Mountain. Like always.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Uh-huh. Only in her case I guess it would be Queen Shit of Turd Mountain. Hand me that adjustable.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Yeah, Winesburg, Ohio, was never like that... but I got something that just might cheer you up.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Wait, dear boy. Just wait. Hand me those pliars.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You got a pilot's license, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Do I need one?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: We're gonna find out. Take it down the road a ways and back. Be careful.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You gave me a heart attack, Marty. I'm dying. I hope you're happy, because you are looking at a dying man.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It really goes fast. Thanks, Uncle Al.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: It goes fast, all right- and if your mother finds out just how fast, Marty, I will have a new job. Singing soprano with the Vienna Boys' Choir.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't get you.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I know you don't. But I want this to be our secret. You get that, don't you?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Now I said I had something for you, as I believe you will recall.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah! What is it?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Stay near the house, for Christ's sake- someone's killing people. I have to be out of my mind to be doing this, you know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, I know. It's great!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: One of the reasons I love you, Marty, is that you're almost as crazy as I am. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay? Just bright colors. Can you tell the difference?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah... sure.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Save this one for last.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: A tracer. You'll like it.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Thanks a million, Uncle Al!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You're welcome a million, Marty. Stick 'em in the bushes for now.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It came for me! I shot it in the eye! Now he's wearing an eye-patch!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I called Peltzer on my way over here, Marty! Father Lowe came into the drugstore two days ago for a bottle of otic solution. That's a fancy way of saying eyewash. He's got a corneal inflammation.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Was it a prescription?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: What the hell does that matter?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It wasn't- I'll bet you it wasn't. Because to get a prescription he'd have to see a doctor.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Marty, Marty, you should hear yourself!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well... was it a prescription?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I don't know. But I know you didn't see any werewolf the other night, Marty. You had a dream, that's all. An extremely realistic nightmare brought on by what's been happening in this town.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What about the baseball bat Jane saw in his shed? You know who used to have a baseball bat like that? Mr. Knopfler! He was so proud of it he used to carry it in the Fourth of July parade! Jane said it looked like the Green Giant used it for a toothpick!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You want to know what I think?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No- we just got you out here so we could admire your pretty face.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Watch it, dear boy. I think it was a hallucination. Probably a broomstick, or something.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'll bet you a quarter that eyewash stuff was nonprescription. And I'll bet you another quarter he hasn't said anything to Mr. Haller.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Marty, do you see your suspect?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Do you really think that a man who took a rocket in the eye three nights ago could be out mowing his lawn? He'd either be in the hospital... or dead.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I didn't shoot him when he was a man. I shot him when he was-

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: When he was a werewolf. Yes. Right. Jesus. Jane, you don't really believe this madness, do you?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Well... it's a lot easier to swallow without the hair and the foaming jaws. Also, I checked on the otic solution. It was counter brand. No prescription needed.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I told you!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Shut up, dear boy- no gloating allowed.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: After Marty called me with his latest Thrilling Tale of Wonder, I did.  He's had no poison-pen complaints lodged at all.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I told you!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: No... but I found some blood, smeared on a tree trunk in that grove.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: There! You see!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: It could have been anything, Marty.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What about Father Lowe chasing me in his car and trying to run me down? You don't think that was a dream, do you?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Mr. Haller said he'd check him out, and guess what? No one sees him again!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: And what do you suggest I do about it, dear boy?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I want you to turn this into a silver bullet.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: You're not going to let it go, are you?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I saw what I saw.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Marty, the moon wasn't even full!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No one knows how cancer begins, either- or exactly what it is- but people still believe in it.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: The kid is eleven years old and already he sounds like a Jesuit. A French Jesuit.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I think he's going to come for me. Not just because I know who he is, but because I hurt him. Only I don't think he'll try again as Lowe.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Dear boy, you have gone right out of your mind.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Will you do it?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah? Really?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Yeah. Really. The bitch of it is, we still are. Learn from your elders, dearies.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I suppose so. You kids ought to go up to bed.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But Uncle Al! You said-

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I know what I said, Marty- but it's ten past one. He's not coming.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What if I say no?

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: Then I'd have to kick your ass, dear boy.  Go on, now.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: I come here because Marty needs a friend.

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: Yes... you've always been that to him. But if you can't leave your booze in whatever dump you call home, you better just stay away.

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: So have I, actually... I wish it could always be like this.

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: See me around to my car, Marty, and make sure I stay out of trouble at least that long.

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: Remember, Al... we'll be at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston tomorrow night! Or at the funeral parlor. It's Stickney and-

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: -and Babcock, I remember. Now go on!

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: And don't open the door for any trick or treaters even if they come!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: We won't!

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: You kids go to bed on time! You've got school tomorrow!

turns.speaker: UNCLE AL
turns.text: If you keep doing that, you're going to bump your head, sissy. Give my love to Mama- tell her I'll see her Thursday.

turns.speaker: NAN
turns.text: I will- be good, kids.

turns.speaker: BISHOP O'HARA
turns.text: Reverend Mother, I just wanted to congratulate you.

turns.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: BISHOP O'HARA
turns.text: I haven't enjoyed Mass this much in years.  What a marvelous program. Innovative.  Inspiring.  You are to be commended.

turns.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
turns.text: Well... thank you.

turns.speaker: BISHOP O'HARA
turns.text: I can't wait until next Sunday, when the choir performs again.  Did you see the people walk right in from the street? That music, that heavenly music -- it called to them.

turns.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
turns.text: Perhaps.

turns.speaker: BISHOP O'HARA
turns.text: I must tell the Cardinal.  I.11 send him a personal letter, describing your efforts, your bold new fight to keep your little convent alive.

turns.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: CHARLENE
turns.text: Yeah.  Sister Mary Pat was discussing it.  You know she thinks it's a sin.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Well... yes.  Yes it is.

turns.speaker: CHARLENE
turns.text: Yeah.  We all got caught.  Shoplifting. Cuttin' school.  Cuttin' up some bitch with a blade.  So we gotta come here.  So we'll be good, in the future.  So we'll learn valuable lessons.  And I learned mine.  I will be incredibly good, I will never rip out nobody's nose-ring by accident ever again.  Can I go now?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Yeah, you learned a whole lot, I can tell.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Okay, so maybe I'm a nun -- so, you want to ask me something?  You want to listen, for once in your little lives? You want to pay some attention?

turns.speaker: CHARLENE
turns.text: What about crack?  You a user?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I said I was a nun, not an asshole.

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY THOUGHTS BE GUIDED

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: What you say?

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY SOUL BE HEALED

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: But how?

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: BY A VOICE YOU HEAR FROM ON HIGH

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I think I hear it!

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY THOUGHTS BE GUIDED

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: You know, I just might!

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY SOUL BE HEALED

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY SPIRIT

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: You know what we're saying!

turns.speaker: CHOIR
turns.text: LET THY SPIRIT

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I think they hear you!
